channel.title: WSJ.com: Economy
channel.copyright: Copyright © Dow Jones & Company, Inc. All rights reserved.

item.title: President Trump’s surprise tariff threat against the EU came in the midst of deepening frustration on his economic team over the 27-nation bloc’s approach to taxes, regulations and China
item.description: The president’s economic team has been frustrated by what it says is the slow pace of talks.
item.dc:creator: Kim Mackrael

item.title: Trump fired new salvos in the global trade war, threatening a 50% tariff on imported goods from the EU and new duties on iPhones and other smartphones made overseas
item.description: President Trump fired new salvos in the global trade war, threatening a 50% tariff on imported goods from the European Union and new duties on iPhones and other smartphones made overseas.
item.dc:creator: Rolfe Winkler

item.title: Here’s where things stand on President Trump’s tariffs
item.description: The basics on the president’s far-reaching protectionist agenda.
item.dc:creator: Jeanne Whalen

item.title: Trump is threatening to ramp up the U.S. trade war with Europe, and costs to move products like cars, pharmaceutical products and airplane parts across the Atlantic are at stake
item.description: A new Trump tariff threat targets a bloc of 27 countries that add up to the largest U.S. trade partner.
item.dc:creator: Inti Pacheco

item.title: Week Ahead for FX, Bonds: Focus on Trade News, PCE Inflation Data and Fed Minutes
item.description: President Trump’s threat of hefty tariffs on EU goods will raise further fears about high U.S. inflation and weak economic growth.
item.dc:creator: Jihye Lee

item.title: First-Time Home Buyers Downsize Amid Tight Supply, High Interest Rates
item.description: Home buyers are more willing to sacrifice size if it means finding a listing that works within their budget.
item.dc:creator: Denny Jacob

item.title: The global savings glut is over, governments have to pay up to borrow—and the U.S. situation is especially risky, WSJ chief economics commentator @greg_ip writes
item.description: The global savings glut is over and governments have to pay up to borrow; the U.S. situation is especially risky.
item.dc:creator: Greg Ip

item.title: Bank of Canada Gov. Tiff Macklem said Thursday the economy risks weakening further unless there is a relatively quick resolution to the U.S.-Canada trade conflict
item.description: Following the end of the Group of Seven meeting of finance and central bank chiefs, Macklem said he expects first-quarter GDP data to show weak consumer spending and business investment.
item.dc:creator: Paul Vieira

item.title: Officials from G-7 nations offered few details about their economic summit. U.S. officials have discussed whether allies would work toward a unified tariff policy on China to pressure Beijing
item.description: Finance and central bank chiefs from the Group of Seven nations offered few details about their economic summit. U.S. officials have discussed whether allies would work toward a unified tariff policy on China to pressure Beijing.
item.dc:creator: Paul Vieira

item.title: Europe and Japan See Drops in Business Activity as U.S. Rebounds
item.description: Business activity in Europe and Japan declined in May, while the U.S. saw a rebound as changes in tariffs continued to have unpredictable consequences for the global economy.
item.dc:creator: Paul Hannon

item.title: Sales of existing homes declined in April, after mounting economic uncertainty and steep housing costs pushed buyers away for the second consecutive month
item.description: The slowest sales pace for any April in 16 years indicates the spring selling season is shaping up as a bust.
item.dc:creator: Nicole Friedman

item.title: RBA Upbeat On China’s Ability to Ride Out Trade War
item.description: Business leaders in China are confident about its strong negotiating position on trade, the RBA deputy governor said following a trip to the country.
item.dc:creator: James Glynn

item.title: BOJ Board Member Noguchi Calls for ‘Measured, Step-By-Step Approach’ to Rate Hikes
item.description: Bank of Japan policy board member Asahi Noguchi struck a more cautious tone about the pace of the bank’s future interest-rate hikes, saying it should take “a measured, step-by-step approach.”
item.dc:creator: Megumi Fujikawa

item.title: U.S. Trade Deals With Allies ‘Suboptimal’ Solution to Tariff Drag, EU’s Dombrovskis Says
item.description: A string of U.S.-led deals with key trading partners could help reduce heightened uncertainty in the business community and financial markets but represent a “suboptimal” solution, says the European Union’s top economic official.
item.dc:creator: Paul Vieira

item.title: Indonesia’s Central Bank Resumes Rate Cuts to Support Growth
item.description: Bank Indonesia has resumed its rate-cutting cycle as cooling inflation, slower growth and a steadier rupiah offer room to loosen policy settings.
item.dc:creator: Ying Xian Wong

item.title: Japan’s Exports to U.S. Fall as Tariffs Start to Bite
item.description: Exports to the U.S. dropped 1.8% in April from a year earlier, reflecting weaker demand for Japanese cars and other machinery.
item.dc:creator: Megumi Fujikawa

item.title: President Trump has pledged to bring more factory work back to the U.S., but many manufacturing jobs are already going unfilled
item.description: The president has pledged to bring more factory work back to the U.S., but many manufacturing jobs are already going unfilled.
item.dc:creator: Te-Ping Chen

item.title: The U.S. hammered out a trade truce with China in record time. Reaching agreement with longtime allies is proving more of a slog.
item.description: Talks with Japan, South Korea and the European Union have bogged down over auto tariffs and the U.S.’s reneging on past deals.
item.dc:creator: Timothy W. Martin

item.title: The University of Michigan said Friday its preliminary index of consumer sentiment for May was 50.8, down about 3% from a final reading of 52.2 in April
item.description: The University of Michigan’s closely watched consumer-sentiment index was 50.8 in preliminary numbers for May.
item.dc:creator: Chao Deng

item.title: U.S. Housing Starts Ticked Up in April
item.description: The gauge of new residential construction rose 1.6% last month to 1.36 million, according to the Commerce Department.
item.dc:creator: Ed Frankl

item.title: Rebound Leaves Asset Prices out of Line With Geopolitical Risks, Says ECB’s De Guindos
item.description: Investors were again underestimating the risk of disruptions to the global economy, and a fresh bout of sharp price falls is possible, the ECB’s vice president warned Thursday.
item.dc:creator: Paul Hannon

item.title: Heard on the Street: Some indicators suggest that youngish prospective homeowners are increasingly struggling to enter the market
item.description: Even with construction companies offering cheap mortgages, youngish people are finding it difficult to enter the market.
item.dc:creator: Carol Ryan

item.title: The troubled housing market can’t seem to get back on track.
item.description: Although inventory has been rising, high home prices and mortgage rates are putting off buyers during the prime selling season.
item.dc:creator: Nicole Friedman

item.title: Jobless Claims Fell Last Week
item.description: The Labor Department said that 228,000 filed new jobless claims in the week through May 3, down from 241,000 a week earlier. Economists polled by The Wall Street Journal had expected to see 230,000 new filings.
item.dc:creator: Matt Grossman

item.title: Major U.S. employers are starting to take a new approach to jobs: Hire less—or not at all
item.description: Most employers aren’t laying off workers, but many have paused hiring while the trade war plays out
item.dc:creator: Lauren Weber

item.title: The spring home-buying season is off to a slow start—but not everywhere
item.description: Markets in Florida and Texas with lots of inventory are posting the biggest price declines, while prices in the Northeast and Midwest are still rising.
item.dc:creator: Max Rust

item.title: The U.S. labor market steadily added jobs last month despite jolting tariff announcements that many economists expect will give way to a trade policy-induced slowdown later this year
item.description: The labor market steadily added jobs despite tariff announcements that many economists expect will give way to a slowdown later this year.
item.dc:creator: Justin Lahart

item.title: President Trump is right to see global trade imbalances as a problem, writes Ed Conway. Can a proposed ’Mar-a-Lago Accord’ fix them?
item.description: The great economist John Maynard Keynes once proposed an international system to eliminate trade surpluses and deficits. Now the ‘Mar-a-Lago Accord’ aims to bring that idea to life.
item.dc:creator: Ed Conway

item.title: Eurozone Inflation Holds Close to Target, Lining Up New Rate Cuts to Counter Tariffs
item.description: Consumer-price inflation in the eurozone remained just above the ECB’s target, teeing up more interest-rate cuts as policymakers anticipate a hit to growth from higher U.S. tariffs.
item.dc:creator: Joshua Kirby

item.title: The April data on jobs and unemployment to be released Friday will give more information on the broader impact of President Trump’s tariffs than the quarterly GDP report did, columnist Greg Ip writes
item.description: Friday’s report will provide the first “hard” data since President Trump’s April 2 tariff announcements.
item.dc:creator: Greg Ip

item.title: Commodity Prices Set to Tumble as Tariffs Slow Global Economy
item.description: The World Bank said it expects commodity prices to fall sharply this year and next as rising tariffs lead to a slowdown in the global economy.
item.dc:creator: Paul Hannon

item.title: Ireland’s Economy Surges as U.S. Businesses Stockpile Ahead of Possible Tariffs
item.description: The economy surged as U.S. pharmaceutical giants based in the country boosted production to build stockpiles back home ahead of threatened tariffs.
item.dc:creator: Paul Hannon

item.title: Heard on the Street: Fear of rising prices can make upfront purchases rational for some groups, but not all
item.description: Fear of rising prices can make upfront purchases rational for some groups, but not all.
item.dc:creator: Telis Demos

item.title: Americans are feeling gloomy about the economy after President Trump’s market-rattling first few months in office. But overall they are keeping the economy humming—for now.
item.description: People are still buying things at a steady clip, keeping the economy humming—for now.
item.dc:creator: Rachel Louise Ensign

item.title: American households ended April feeling much worse about the economy than they did in March, according to a closely watched measure of consumer sentiment
item.description: Households ended April feeling much worse about the economy than they did in March, according to a closely watched measure of consumer sentiment.
item.dc:creator: Harriet Torry

item.title: U.K. Consumers’ Mood Darkens Under Tariff Clouds
item.description: Consumers in the U.K. are growing more pessimistic as they fear the weight of trade tariffs and renewed high inflation, according to research group GfK.
item.dc:creator: Joshua Kirby
